Vlaakith: Inquisitor W'wargaz was potent. We are impressed.
NodeContext: Vlaakith should sligjhtly overpronounce every word, think Davros from Doctor Who, each syllable drips with a kind of mad, ancient evil
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The planecaster vibrates, shaking the ground around it.
Flares of light curl up in its centre and grow to full form.
Vlaakith appears, awesome and terrible, at least twice the size of any human, a hologram in a haze of astral flares.
Flares of light curl up in its centre and grow to full form.
Vlaakith appears, awesome and terrible, at least twice the size of any human, a hologram in a haze of astral flares.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: Vlaakith gha'g shkath zai!
NodeContext: pronounced VLAH-kith gawg shkaath ZAI (meaning 'For the honour of Vlaakith!')
Lae'zel: My queen.
Narrator: *The queen who brings conquest to the heavens, sundering planets, destroying the very stars.*
Narrator: *Hot envy swirls within. Your guts will you to author such cosmic tragedies as she has.*
Vlaakith: You are permitted to look upon me. You are invited to kneel.
Player: Wave politely.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The player waves politely at Vlaakith.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The Inquisitor frowns at your insolence.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: I expected little of istik education, but here we kneel before our queen.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Vlaakith, unfazed in the least, considers you with critical interest.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Vlaakith looms in to face the player at their eye level.
Vlaakith: You bear that which is ours. But are you friend, or are you thief?
Player: Friend - I came to bring it back to you.
Astarion: You're what? That is the only thing keeping us from a gruesome, tentacled-filled future.
Vlaakith: An unexpected servant. Your will is strong.
Vlaakith: Your kind is not known for trusting strangers. Quite rightly. Yet here you are.
Vlaakith: Extend your fealty one step further, and you will be rewarded beyond your mortal reckoning.
Vlaakith: The Astral Prism - it is corrupted.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: I shall cleanse it for you, my queen. Tell me how.
InternalNodeContext: He's not altogether sure why this task is falling to the player and not to him, but also doesn't want to challenge his queen's motivations.
Vlaakith: SILENCE, W'wargaz.
Vlaakith: There is someone inside. Their mind is warped, broken - a blight.
Vlaakith: They are an agent of the Grand Design. Sent to sabotage the Astral Prism - our last defence against the return of the Illithid Empire.
Vlaakith: As long as they live, the Prism is compromised.
Vlaakith: Find the one inside and kill them. Be aware - they are not alone, and they will appeal to your trust. They are not to be believed.
Vlaakith: You must accept. Refuse, and know my fury.
Player: I will do as you wish.

Alfira: You're all right! Thank goodness, I was worried they'd got you too.
NodeContext: Relieved. Trying to be cheerful but you're upset, and just holding it together.
Player: I heard what happened - that people were taken to Moonrise.
Alfira: I keep replaying it... over and over in my head.
Alfira: We were ambushed out in the darkness - by cultists. We surrendered, but that wasn't enough for them.
Alfira: They lined us up like dogs. Asharak was with the kids, telling them it was gonna be all right.
Alfira: Maybe that's why they picked him. Told him to kneel...
Alfira: They took his eyes first. Then his tongue.
Player: I've seen a lot of nasty ambushes in my time - but that sounds among the worst. I'm sorry.
Alfira: It just... it just never stops.
Alfira: Rolan, of all people, saved us.
Alfira: He said he stayed in the grove because of you, and I'm damn glad of it. Without him... well, none of us would be here.
Player: What did the cultists do to the others?
Alfira: I don't know. It just... happened so quickly.
Alfira: How do you do it? How do you keep going?
Player: A strong weapon-arm and a bit of luck. That's all you need.
Alfira: You're made of sterner stuff than me then.
Alfira: You've done so much for us already, but I have to ask - the others might still be out there.
Alfira: If they're not dead, they're in Moonrise. And gods have mercy on anyone in that hellspit.
Player: I imagine the cultists are torturing them right now.

He Who Was: Madeline's spirit is within reach. It is time to make her face trial, to make her suffer.
He Who Was: And you will be the judge. Make her beg, make her suffer.
Player: I'm going to punish her - throughly.
He Who Was: The raven was right, we were fated to meet. Break her, my friend - most thoroughly.
He Who Was: Witness her.
NodeContext: low, excited voice. Eyes roll back in his head as he looks up - body jerking. Falls to his knees.
Madeline: You! He said I was gonna be punished, that you'd be the judge. But I didn't mean to hurt anyone!
Player: You 'didn't mean' to kill your friends? How laughable.
Astarion: Well now, let's not throwing stones. Glass houses and all that.
Madeline: I said it didn't mean nothin', that Ben n' Marc were just drunk n' whining.
Madeline: The Dark Justiciar promised she was gonna chat with 'em. She promised.
Player: My gorge rises at your sickening naivety.
Madeline: No - no that wasn't the worst of it.
Madeline: She gave 'em a dagger each, and told 'em to press it against their stomachs.
Madeline: On the count of three, to 'start stabbin', and not to stop 'til she said so.
Madeline: She never said stop. I'd do anything to take it back. Anything.
Player: Stab yourself. Rip your stomach open. Feel the pain of your friends - only then will you be free.
Player: Anything? Then hurt yourself as Ben and Marc did - stab yourself.
Madeline: Like... this?
NodeContext: Madeline draws a blade from behind her and holds it in front of her stomach, blade pointed towards her stomach. She is utterly terrified (pose like seppuku)
Player: Prove you're sorry. Do it for Ben and Marc.
Madeline: Ah! I'm sorry.
NodeContext: Ah! is a noise of pain as she stabs herself in the stomach and then pulls out the knife. 'I'm sorry' is said in clear pain.
Madeline: Argh. I'm so sorry.
NodeContext: stabs herself again on 'Argh', noise of pain. I'm so so sorry is half crying as she's in agony.
Player: Stop. You've done enough.

Gauntlet Edwynna: No refugees. It is decreed.
Gauntlet Edwynna: Halt! By orders of Lord Gortash, refugees are no longer allowed in the city. Turn around.
Player: I'm not a refugee.
Gauntlet Edwynna: Well, do you have the means to support yourself? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Player: I can take care of myself. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Gauntlet Edwynna: Right. Article 30.1.5 of the Council's Decree on Extraordinary Wartime Measures. I am confiscating that. The city thanks you for your contribution.
Gauntlet Edwynna: Your name?
Player: My name is [GEN_PlayerName_c11eee1e-7815-6143-7233-f2427799fa53].
GROUP_SteelWatchers: Well met, citizen.
Narrator: *Your parasite stirs. From the construct, you feel connection. Resonance.*
Player: Can I go now?
Gauntlet Edwynna: Not just yet.
Gauntlet Edwynna: State your business.
Wyll: My good lady. I am Wyll Ravengard. My business is the city's business.
Gauntlet Edwynna: Wyll Ravengard? Of course, of course - the city is always open to you. But I'm afraid you'll still need to comply with new protocol. By Lord Gortash's command.
Player: I have an urgent message for Duke Ulder Ravengard.
Gauntlet Edwynna: Uh-huh. Eyes open, body still.
NodeContext: "Uh-huh" as in, "Yes, I heard you and am going with it."
Player: Do as she says. Stand still.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The steel watcher steps forward and begins to scan the player's eyes.
There is NO mindmeld, because player is NOT tadpoled.
There is NO mindmeld, because player is NOT tadpoled.
Narrator: *Behind the Watcher's gaze, a presence awakens. You may not carry a mind flayer parasite, but it sees you - knows you.*
Narrator: *Behind the Watcher's gaze, a presence awakens. You are seen, you are known.*
Narrator: *Your infernal machinery seems to snap to attention, almost singing in recognition.*
Karlach: Whoa. My engine. It's almost... I don't know. Buzzing. Like it's paying attention.
Narrator: *Your party's prior transgressions are reflected in its stare, as witnessed by the cult's ever-alert scrying eyes.*
Narrator: *It has heard the howls of slaughtered goblins.*
Narrator: *It has seen the deep shadows of Grymforge, and the stone floors left bloodied.*
Narrator: *It knows the cold walls of Moonrise Towers, and the cultists who fell there.*
Narrator: *The Watcher speaks directly into your mind with a voice like poisoned honey.*
GROUP_SteelWatchers: You are marked for special treatment. Not simply an enemy of the people, but an enemy of the Absolute. Come quietly, or die.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Mindmeld with steel watcher ends
Player: Ready yourself for a fight.

Balthazar: Finally, we can talk face-to-face.
Balthazar: Not just any True Soul would have succeeded in following my path through this place. You should be pleased.
Balthazar: I take it the breaking of my skeletons was an accident - the living are so clumsy, after all.
Player: I'm pleased to be of service, Balthazar.
Balthazar: Perhaps you can prove to me that you're more useful alive than dead. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Balthazar: But you're here now, and I may be able to put those limbs to work. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Player: Z'rell spoke of a relic - something called the Nightsong in your notes. They were very interesting.
Player: Yet you seem no closer to retrieving the Nightsong? I read your notes - very interesting.
Balthazar: Interesting, and private. Give me one reason why I shouldn't have my creations kill you right now, thief.
Player: You are a ship without a sail, necromancer. You need allies - you need me.
Player: It's simple - you need me. Don't pretend otherwise.
Balthazar: ...Fine. Your usefulness may outweigh your insolence - for now. There are much grander things at stake.
NodeContext: A pause before 'fine' - weighing up the player's fate.
Balthazar: The Nightsong is my finest creation - if I never exceed myself, I will still die happy. Not that I ever intend to do something as gauche as truly dying, of course.
Balthazar: Now, given your prying nature, I have work for you, as a scout.
Balthazar: The Nightsong lends the General his strength, his invulnerability. It must be recovered, before his enemies attempt to exploit it.
Player: You need my help?
Balthazar: I do not need you, or your help. But you are here in spite of that, so I may as well make use of you.
Balthazar: The relic is close, but the way is barred and Shar's dead are... uncooperative. Clear the path for me - by blade, cunning, or whatever it takes.
Balthazar: I will remain here until you have succeeded, or fallen.
Shadowheart: I'd trust this gasbag about as far as I can throw him - which isn't far. But perhaps better to play along, for now.
Player: For jobs like this it's good form to provide your operatives some extra resources.
Balthazar: Fine. I will assign Flesh to aid you on your way. Ring this bell...
Balthazar: ...Hmm. Misplaced, it seems. You will be capable enough without it.
Player: I'll see what I can do.

NodeContext: Begrudging and largely hostile, but with a hint of appreciation for the player's skill in actually making it this far.
Balthazar: Not just any True Soul would have succeeded in following my path through this place. You should be pleased.

Balthazar: I do not cower - I plan. I command. I create.
Balthazar: General Thorm trusts me. He knows I will deliver. He knows I will stand by him long after all others wilt and fall.
Balthazar: You, Z'rell, all the rest... you have only one body with which to serve. I have as many as I care to make.

Halsin: Pardon the viscera. One should cherish all of nature's bounty... but goblin guts are quite far down the list.
NodeContext: Hint of wry humour, Introducing himself after transforming from an owlbear and killing several goblins.
Halsin: Not only do you speak with a bear, but you free it, too? A true friend of nature - or perhaps a lunatic.
Halsin: Either way, I owe thanks. I am the druid Halsin.
Player: Glad I could be of help.
Halsin: I must admit, I didn't expect anyone would come to my aid. Who in their right mind would infiltrate a goblin infested temple. Unless...
Halsin: ...Hrrm. That look in your eyes - I've seen it before. Are you feeling all right?
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Halsin raises a hand to your head, magically connecting with you (no contact). He gives an alarmed look - he knows what’s inside you
Halsin: Oak Father preserve you, child... You're infected, aren't you? The mind flayers' spawn.
Halsin: But... something's different. You're aware of the monster inside you. You don't bow to the Absolute, like the True Souls do...
Halsin: How is this possible...?
Player: I think this artefact has something to do with it.
Halsin: Hmmm... that looks very alien. As alien as the mind flayers. They do not belong on this world.
Halsin: It's no coincidence that you found me here, I'll wager? You're after a cure for this parasite.
Halsin: I've been studying these parasites for a while now. Ever since I discovered these so-called True Souls are infected with them.
Halsin: Someone is using very powerful magic to modify these tadpoles. They are using them to exert control over the infected.
Halsin: I'm sorry to say, I can't undo that magic, which means I can't cure you. But that doesn't mean I can't help.
Halsin: I didn't find what I came here for - a way to remove the tadpoles - but I found the next best thing. I found out where they come from.
Halsin: That must be where these enchantments are placed on them, and it's where you'll find your cure.
Player: Tell me what you've learned about the tadpoles' origins.
Halsin: I overheard that the cultists are sending all of their captives to Moonrise Towers.
Halsin: Innocents go in, True Souls come out. Given that all of these True Souls are infected, it has to be the source of this magic.
Halsin: If you want to find a cure, you must head there and discover how the tadpoles are being manipulated.
Player: Altered parasites? A cure at Moonrise Towers, maybe? Sounds like guesswork at best.
Halsin: I'm as certain as I can be. If you have a better alternative, I won't stop you.
Halsin: I can't stop you, in fact. Which brings me to my next problem...
Halsin: I've no right to ask more of you... but if you could help me, I'd be free to join your journey to Moonrise.
Halsin: I cannot allow these butchers to threaten my grove. The natural order must be protected.
Player: Look around you - there's no order anymore. Only chaos.
Halsin: Chaos is welcome, in doses; it helps keep balance. But this is too much - this is unnatural.
Halsin: It's too late to merely kill this horde's leadership - their forces are already marching. If you want me to help, you need to help me first.
Halsin: You must get ahead of them, muster the defences.
Player: You ask too much of me. I can't help you.

Nightwarden Minthara: You killed the dead man. I'm impressed.
Nightwarden Minthara: And now your path takes you to Baldur's Gate. I shall walk that path with you.
Player: I hoped you would - we make a good team.
Player: And I'll never tire of killing their previous occupants. We make a good team.

Nightwarden Minthara: It is clear, now, that he was not working alone.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Leaves throne, standing from here on
Nightwarden Minthara: We must be free if we are to rule - and to be free, we must destroy this cult, and Ketheric's co-conspirators along with it.
Nightwarden Minthara: I know one of them all too well - Bhaal's blood-letter, Orin.
Nightwarden Minthara: To think I thought her to be speaking for the Absolute. I worshipped that woman.
Player: An old flame?

Nightwarden Minthara: She is the iblith who indoctrinated me with the Absolute's lies.
Nightwarden Minthara: Indeed, she is the one who indoctrinated me with the Absolute's lies.
Player: What do you remember of your indoctrination?
Nightwarden Minthara: When I first visited Moonrise, I stood before the Absolute in awe.
Nightwarden Minthara: It was more of an idea than an entity. Pure love. Total power.
Nightwarden Minthara: Orin was by my side. She told me that god had chosen me to be a True Soul. Blessed and adored.
Nightwarden Minthara: Now I know that those memories are lies.
Nightwarden Minthara: There was no god. Orin held me down in a cocoon of flesh, while a mind flayer forced a parasite into my brain. And she laughed at my fear.
Nightwarden Minthara: I will find her, I will murder her. And I will smile.
Player: We'll be heroes - the saviours of Baldur's Gate.
Nightwarden Minthara: Let them think that. There is a short path from saviour to ruler - a short and bloody path. I know it well, and we will walk it together.
Nightwarden Minthara: But Baldur's Gate is a mere bauble. We have the chance to seize something much greater. Surely you see it?
Nightwarden Minthara: In killing Ketheric, we fractured the cult's leadership. When we break the other Chosen and claim their Netherstones, we can take control.
Player: A bold gamble. How can you be sure it's possible?
Nightwarden Minthara: I would have thought this entire conspiracy of gods and monsters to be impossible if I had not seen it for myself.
Nightwarden Minthara: We may fail, but we must try.
Nightwarden Minthara: The power of the enslaved elder brain could reshape the world. We could reshape the world.
Player: I fear we could lose everything if we try to take control.
Nightwarden Minthara: Nothing worthwhile ever came without loss. But together we have the strength to decide who loses. And to make sure it is not us.
Nightwarden Minthara: You are not stupid. When we reach Baldur's Gate and face the other Chosen, you will see that my way is the right one.
Player: You may be right. I'll keep an open mind.
Nightwarden Minthara: That is all I ask. And remember, I know when your mind is closed.
Nightwarden Minthara: We are bound, then, to travel together, even if we do not yet agree on our ultimate purpose.
Nightwarden Minthara: There is yet one thing about you that troubles me, though. Something I need you to explain.
Nightwarden Minthara: When we killed the tieflings, at the grove, I was not in control of my actions. You do not have that excuse. So I ask you - why? Why kill them?

Sarevok Anchev: She dreams that your corpse will be her masterpiece, but she forgets - before your incident, you were the true master.
Sarevok Anchev: You were murder. Pure murder. No excesses. No pretentions.
Sarevok Anchev: I believe you will be the one to slay Orin.
Sarevok Anchev: But you will need my help.
Sarevok Anchev: I see you have not embraced your birthright yet. Perhaps with my stewardship,
Father will bless you yet.
Sarevok Anchev: And when he does, remember grandfather Sarevok. Remember how he helped you. Return to visit him, and tell the blood-drenched tale of your victory.
Sarevok Anchev: Before you may return to our Father's fold, I must first ensure that you remain as pure and worthy of his blessing as you once were.
Sarevok Anchev: So I ask -  why have you brought no offering, child of Bhaal? How am I to lead you in his worship, if you abstain from his most blessed sacrement?
Sarevok Anchev: Come, child of Murder, let me lead you in Bhaal's worship.
Player: I will make Bhaal proud.
Sarevok Anchev: You misunderstand the Lord of Murder. He is not proud. He simply is.
Sarevok Anchev: Let us begin.
Sarevok Anchev: Spirit of the slaughtered - return to us.
Sarevok Anchev: Show us the truth of this murderer's intent, and let us judge them for their bloody service.
Echo of Amelyssan: His will be done.
[description] NodeContext: Sarevok stands
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Sarevok reaches out his hand, and clenches it as though grasping something tight. He pulls the hand back towards himself, and a roiling, miasma of dark magic streams from off stage into a large cloud in front of the tribunal
[description] CinematicNodeContext: the cloud of dark energy clears. The spectre of our previous victim stands before the player. It is confused, scared, and tries to speak, but no noise escapes.
GROUP_Emperors: Can it be - Belynne herself, reduced to a spectre...
Sarevok Anchev: You took this spirit's life, and thus, its voice. So, speak for it. How was this pitiable creature slain?
Player: With a smile on my face, and pleasure in my heart.

Halsin: Pardon the viscera. One should cherish all of nature's bounty... but goblin guts are quite far down the list.
NodeContext: Hint of wry humour, Introducing himself after transforming from an owlbear and killing several goblins.
Halsin: Not only do you speak with a bear, but you free it, too? A true friend of nature - or perhaps a lunatic.
Halsin: Either way, I owe thanks. I am the druid Halsin.
Player: Glad I could be of help.
Halsin: I must admit, I didn't expect anyone would come to my aid. Who in their right mind would infiltrate a goblin infested temple. Unless...
Halsin: ...Hrrm. That look in your eyes - I've seen it before. Are you feeling all right?
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Halsin raises a hand to your head, magically connecting with you (no contact). He gives an alarmed look - he knows what’s inside you
Halsin: Oak Father preserve you, child... You're infected, aren't you? The mind flayers' spawn.
Halsin: But... something's different. You're aware of the monster inside you. You don't bow to the Absolute, like the True Souls do...
Halsin: How is this possible...?
Player: I escaped from an illithid ship after being infected. Maybe the process was interrupted.
Halsin: Perhaps... but I wouldn't want to place all my faith in blind luck.
Halsin: You weren't speaking lightly when you said you needed help. Let me tell you what I know.
Halsin: I've been studying these parasites for a while now. Ever since I discovered these so-called True Souls are infected with them.
Halsin: Someone is using very powerful magic to modify these tadpoles. They are using them to exert control over the infected.
Halsin: I'm sorry to say, I can't undo that magic, which means I can't cure you. But that doesn't mean I can't help.
Halsin: I didn't find what I came here for - a way to remove the tadpoles - but I found the next best thing. I found out where they come from.
Halsin: That must be where these enchantments are placed on them, and it's where you'll find your cure.
Player: How did you come to study mind flayer parasites?
Halsin: A drow forced me to defend myself. Afterwards, I was able to study the parasite that slithered out of the corpse, see what drives these 'True Souls'.
Halsin: I had no idea anyone beyond their ranks was infected. You have my sincere sympathies.
Player: This magic you mentioned - it isn't normal for these parasites?
Player: What should I do?
Halsin: I overheard that the cultists are sending all of their captives to Moonrise Towers.
Halsin: Innocents go in, True Souls come out. Given that all of these True Souls are infected, it has to be the source of this magic.
Halsin: If you want to find a cure, you must head there and discover how the tadpoles are being manipulated.
Player: Altered parasites? A cure at Moonrise Towers, maybe? Sounds like guesswork at best.
Halsin: I'm as certain as I can be. If you have a better alternative, I won't stop you.
Halsin: I can't stop you, in fact. Which brings me to my next problem...
Halsin: I've no right to ask more of you... but if you could help me, I'd be free to join your journey to Moonrise.
Halsin: I cannot allow these butchers to threaten my grove. The natural order must be protected.
Player: All right. How do I help?
Halsin: My thanks. If you prevail, I'll owe you the debt of a lifetime.
Halsin: It's too late to stop things from here - the goblins are already marching on the grove in force.
Halsin: You must get ahead of them, muster the defences.
Player: You ask too much of me. I can't help you.

Havkelaag: Ah, a surface dweller.
Havkelaag: You find yourself in the cradle of all knowledge relating to the Underdark: the Society of Brilliance.
Havkelaag: Tell me, what can the Society do for you?
Player: I met an expeditioner claiming to work for you. She sought a githyanki egg.
Havkelaag: Yes, dear Lady Esther. One of our most reliable contractors, though unfortunately this particular request was too much even for her.
Havkelaag: I believe she quite lost her senses over the task. She came here insisting I purchase an owlbear egg from her, of all things.
Havkelaag: I don't suppose you've stumbled across any githyanki eggs during your travels? The Society will compensate you for any we purchase, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Havkelaag: Would you consider parting with it? The Society's coffers are deep enough to cover any expenses accrued in its retrieval, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: Chk. Don't you dare consider it.
Player: What are you going to do with it?
Havkelaag: Study it, of course. Your kind have been a source of great debate in the Society's circles in recent months.
Havkelaag: Most on this plane believe you to be innately cruel, violent beings. Evil, if you will.
Havkelaag: As citizens of the Underdark, we face similar stigmas. Totally unfounded, of course - our natures are as unfixed as any who walk the surface.
Havkelaag: I believe that, if hatched in a morally sound, intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome the evil predisposition its githyanki nature bestows.
Player: What does this 'intellectually stimulating' upbringing look like?
Havkelaag: In the literal sense, I will need to induce the egg to hatch via the application of certain currents to the creature inside.
Havkelaag: Once out of the shell, I plan to take a twofold approach:
Havkelaag: The enforced repetition of sound moral principles from the Ptarian code, alongside a series of psionic pulses administered to the cerebral tissue.
Havkelaag: Assuming I can accelerate its growth, I should have conclusive findings within a year or two at the most.
Player: Why follow the dogma of a draconic god?
Havkelaag: In my years of study, they're the closest I've found to moral perfection. Only under such rigorous 'goodness' will the subject stand a chance of being cured.
Havkelaag: My findings could change the perception of githyanki and the peoples of the Underdark for generations to come.
Player: An experiment like this will only confirm the surface dwellers' suspicion of us.
Havkelaag: Of course it won't. If anything, it will do quite the opposite. The academic institutions up here will finally be forced to take us seriously.
Havkelaag: Now, I'm eager to get started, so will you sell me the egg? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: A gith hatchling is not a lab rat! This shka'keth should be bled dry for the mere suggestion.
Player: Sell the egg.
Havkelaag: Ah. Unfortunately, it seems I've mislaid my purse.
Havkelaag: I don't suppose you'd consider simply donating it to the Society instead?
Player: Fine. Here you go.

Balthazar: Finally, we can talk face-to-face.
Balthazar: Not just any True Soul would have succeeded in following my path through this place. You should be pleased.

Balthazar: But you're here now, and I may be able to put those limbs to work. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Player: Z'rell said Ketheric wants you to find a relic. That's all I know.

Balthazar: General Thorm to you. But yes, recovering the relic is the crux of it. He commands, and I, his humble servant, fulfil that command.

Narrator: *This necromancer has Ketheric's trust. Helping him could be just what you need to gain access to the man himself.*

Player: I need more to go on. Why is this relic so important? What does it do?

Balthazar: The Nightsong lends the General his strength, his invulnerability. It must be recovered, before his enemies attempt to exploit it.
Player: You need my help?
Balthazar: I do not need you, or your help. But you are here in spite of that, so I may as well make use of you.
Balthazar: The Nightsong is close, but the way is barred and Shar's dead are... uncooperative. Clear the path for me - by blade, cunning, or whatever it takes.
Balthazar: I will remain here until you have succeeded, or fallen.

Player: You have resources to spare - give me something to aid my search.
Balthazar: Fine. I will assign Flesh to aid you on your way. Ring this bell...
Balthazar: ...Hmm. Misplaced, it seems. You will be capable enough without it.
Player: This sounds like your problem, not mine.
Player: Keep it - this is your problem, not mine.
Balthazar: This is not a problem - it is an opportunity. And it is not a choice either - you will obey.
Player: Fine. I'll see what I can do.
Player: I'll see what I can do.

NodeContext: Sniffing the air at the start, detecting something - then erupting with fury at the end on 'sulphur'.

NodeContext: Furious

Yurgir: You can't help. It's not just walls that keep me here. Not the traps, the dark or the creatures it hides. Something stronger holds me - a contract.
Yurgir: Either I fulfil the contract, die trying... or forfeit my freedom. If I leave this place now, I'll become Raphael's slave.

NodeContext: singing, a cappella

Havkelaag: Study it, of course. The githyanki have been a source of great debate in the Society's circles in recent months.
Havkelaag: You are no doubt aware that citizens of the Underdark are held in great suspicion by those who live above ground. Many believe us to be 'evil'.
Havkelaag: The githyanki face similar prejudice, but I believe, if hatched in a less violent, more intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome its evil predispositions.
Havkelaag: I believe that, if hatched in a morally sound, intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome the evil predisposition its githyanki nature bestows.
Player: What does this 'intellectually stimulating' upbringing look like?
Havkelaag: In the literal sense, I will need to induce the egg to hatch via the application of certain currents to the creature inside.
Havkelaag: Once out of the shell, I plan to take a twofold approach:
Havkelaag: The enforced repetition of sound moral principles from the Ptarian code, alongside a series of psionic pulses administered to the cerebral tissue.
Havkelaag: Assuming I can accelerate its growth, I should have conclusive findings within a year or two at the most.
Player: Why follow the dogma of a draconic god?
Havkelaag: In my years of study, they're the closest I've found to moral perfection. Only under such rigorous 'goodness' will the subject stand a chance of being cured.
Havkelaag: My findings could change the perception of githyanki and the peoples of the Underdark for generations to come.
Player: Your findings are irrelevant, as are the opinions of all on this kaincha plane.
Havkelaag: Ah. A display of the well-known githyanki arrogance. I am not sure my experiment can cure that particular affliction, but give me time and I will find a way.
Havkelaag: Now, I'm eager to get started, so will you sell me the egg? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: A gith hatchling is not a lab rat! This shka'keth should be bled dry for the mere suggestion.
Player: Sell the egg.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: The player enters the camp, Wyll waiting at a side, fully in view. A diabolical circle draws itself onto the ground in front of you and Wyll, shocked/surprise, and Mizora in devil form rises from it, maybe can have a turn and a noble pose at the end.

Crusher: ...thrashed 'is arm with my bare hands. Weaker than pixies, humans.
NodeContext: This goblin is in the  telling a story to the other goblins. We join the conversation in the middle.
Brawler Tiny: Oh ho, you got 'im good!
Crusher: And what're you doin' 'ere with that stink on yer face? Think you can do whatever you want?
Crusher: Think you rule the world, huh?
Crusher: And who're you? 'Nother pest? Everyone just barges in here, thinkin' they rule the world. Hah!
Narrator: *A strange symbol glows, marked on their flesh, and something within you stirs in response.*
Player: Lot of assumptions here. I don't think I'm better than anyone else.
Crusher: Everyone says that. And then they spit in our faces.
Crusher: But no more. Things're changin'. We got the Absolute on our side now.

Crusher: Ya better learn yer place.

Halsin: Pardon the viscera. One should cherish all of nature's bounty... but goblin guts are quite far down the list.
NodeContext: Hint of wry humour, Introducing himself after transforming from an owlbear and killing several goblins.
Halsin: Not only do you speak with a bear, but you free it, too? A true friend of nature - or perhaps a lunatic.
Halsin: Either way, I owe thanks. I am the druid Halsin.
Player: I spoke to Nettie - she said you could help me with the parasite in my head.
Halsin: Parasite in your head...? You mean you have one of them?
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Halsin raises a hand to your head, magically connecting with you (no contact). He gives an alarmed look - he knows what’s inside you
Halsin: Oak Father preserve you, child... You're infected, aren't you? The mind flayers' spawn.
Halsin: But... something's different. You're aware of the monster inside you. You don't bow to the Absolute, like the True Souls do...
Halsin: How is this possible...?
Player: I escaped from an illithid ship after being infected. Maybe the process was interrupted.
Halsin: Perhaps... but I wouldn't want to place all my faith in blind luck.
Halsin: You weren't speaking lightly when you said you needed help. Let me tell you what I know.
Halsin: I've been studying these parasites for a while now. Ever since I discovered these so-called True Souls are infected with them.
Halsin: Someone is using very powerful magic to modify these tadpoles. They are using them to exert control over the infected.
Halsin: I'm sorry to say, I can't undo that magic, which means I can't cure you. But that doesn't mean I can't help.
Halsin: I didn't find what I came here for - a way to remove the tadpoles - but I found the next best thing. I found out where they come from.
Halsin: That must be where these enchantments are placed on them, and it's where you'll find your cure.
Player: You learned all this from your studies?
Halsin: Indeed. After we dealt with the drow that ambushed us, Nettie and I were able to inspect the corpse - and the creature that slithered out of it.
Halsin: I had no idea anyone beyond their ranks was infected. You have my sincere sympathies.
Player: This magic you mentioned - it isn't normal for these parasites?
Player: Then everything we did here was hopeless.
Halsin: Patience. I can't just snap my fingers... but I know where the solution almost certainly lies.
Halsin: I overheard that the cultists are sending all of their captives to Moonrise Towers.
Halsin: Innocents go in, True Souls come out. Given that all of these True Souls are infected, it has to be the source of this magic.
Halsin: If you want to find a cure, you must head there and discover how the tadpoles are being manipulated.
Player: You seem to know a lot about this. Will you come with me to Moonrise?
Halsin: I wish I could, but there's still work I've yet to finish - blood I've yet to spill.
Halsin: I've no right to ask more of you... but if you could help me, I'd be free to join your journey to Moonrise.
Halsin: I cannot allow these butchers to threaten my grove. The natural order must be protected.
Player: Kagha is dead. She was swayed by Shadow Druids. I had no choice.
Halsin: Kagha... This is my fault - I was her teacher. I will mourn her when I can.
Halsin: But there are other matters to attend to before that.
Halsin: Chaos is welcome, in doses; it helps keep balance. But this is too much - this is unnatural.
Halsin: Help me kill the leaders of this horde, save my grove. Then I will help you.

Halsin: Three deaths could win us peace: the drow Minthara, the hobgoblin Dror Ragzlin, and that perversion of a priestess, Gut.
Halsin: They are the ones holding these parasites together. Remove them and nature will cure itself.
Player: You are aware you're asking me to kill a drow?
Halsin: You drow relish turning on your own, if there's something to be gained. Don't pretend otherwise.
Player: There's no pretence in not wanting to play the assassin. You're on your own.

Vlaakith: So - it is found.
NodeContext: Vlaakith should sligjhtly overpronounce every word, think Davros from Doctor Who, each syllable drips with a kind of mad, ancient evil
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The planecaster vibrates, shaking the ground around it.
Flares of light curl up in its centre and grow to full form.
Vlaakith appears, awesome and terrible, at least twice the size of any human, a hologram in a haze of astral flares.
Flares of light curl up in its centre and grow to full form.
Vlaakith appears, awesome and terrible, at least twice the size of any human, a hologram in a haze of astral flares.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: Vlaakith gha'g shkath zai!
NodeContext: pronounced VLAH-kith gawg shkaath ZAI (meaning 'For the honour of Vlaakith!')
Lae'zel: My queen.
Narrator: *Your vision throbs with ink-black darkness as your patron borrows your gaze - beholding the vision in front of you.*
Narrator: *Not exactly a god - but not far off. Your patron recoils, but not before leaving a word of advice - caution.*
Vlaakith: You are permitted to look upon me. You are invited to kneel.
Player: Stay standing, just as you are.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The Inquisitor frowns at your insolence.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: I expected little of istik education, but here we kneel before our queen.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Vlaakith, unfazed in the least, considers you with critical interest.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Vlaakith looms in to face the player at their eye level.
Vlaakith: You bear that which is ours. But are you friend, or are you thief?
Player: Friend - I came to bring it back to you.
Wyll: Are you mad? That artefact's the only thing shielding us from the Absolute's voice.
Vlaakith: An unexpected servant. Your will is strong.
Vlaakith: Descendant of noble dragons - you honour us with your allyship.
Vlaakith: Extend your fealty one step further, and you will be rewarded beyond your mortal reckoning.
Vlaakith: The Astral Prism - it is corrupted.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: I shall cleanse it for you, my queen. Tell me how.
InternalNodeContext: He's not altogether sure why this task is falling to the player and not to him, but also doesn't want to challenge his queen's motivations.
Vlaakith: SILENCE, W'wargaz.
Vlaakith: There is someone inside. Their mind is warped, broken - a blight.
Vlaakith: They are an agent of the Grand Design. Sent to sabotage the Astral Prism - our last defence against the return of the Illithid Empire.
Vlaakith: As long as they live, the Prism is compromised.
Vlaakith: Find the one inside and destroy them. Be aware - they are not alone, and they will appeal to your trust. They are not to be believed.
Player: It is my greatest honour to obey.

Lord Enver Gortash: You have the Netherstones - they resonate with my own.
Lord Enver Gortash: I commend you for putting an end to Orin's madness - she must be screaming bloody murder in the Hells even now.
Lord Enver Gortash: How was the reunion? I trust you demonstrated your particular spark of creative genius?
Lord Enver Gortash: I always preferred your methods to hers. You have mastery over your Urges, Orin was consumed by her gruesome obsessions.
Player: You're wrong, my Urges are only ever a step away from controlling me.
Lord Enver Gortash: Bhaal allows you to pick your battles, as long as you do pick them. Orin thinks she needs to slash every throat in sight.
Lord Enver Gortash: My involvement with Orin was never a true alliance. A mad dog understands the yank of the leash and the hand of its master, but it cannot be an equal.
Lord Enver Gortash: You can be my equal.
Lord Enver Gortash: We will raise a Black Keep in Baldur's Gate. Then we will conquer the Sword Coast, and unite all its peoples under our rule. But first -
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The room shakes from a "brainquake".
Lord Enver Gortash: The brain awakens - we must act now. Faithful, come forward.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Several Banites step from the corner shadows, one at a time. They look fierce and dangerous.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Finally, the Steel Watcher stepw forward. It activates, looking devastatingly powerful.
Lord Enver Gortash: Hand me the Netherstones, and we will rule as one.
Shadowheart: Good idea. And let's trust the fox to safeguard the chicken coop, while we're at it.

Lord Enver Gortash: I'm not here for games. Hand me the stones, or face the black hand of Lord Bane.
Player: We can be allies but Ketheric and Orin's stones stay with me.

Zethino: This city of stone and steel is an endless scream in nature's womb. I have felt no peace here. Until now.
Zethino: Your eyes, stira. There is pain, endless and deep. But also devotion - blazing like the sun. You're in love, are you not?
Player: I do love someone - someone close to me, actually.
Zethino: You are wise to admit it. When it comes to love, vulnerability is armour. Truth, a sword. And trust, a shield. I pray you wield all three, stira.
Zethino: Bring the one you love to me. I will look into your hearts and see if your love is eternal. Or doomed eternally. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Player: What do you say, Shadowheart?
Shadowheart: Love, is it? I hadn't realised I'd bowled you over that much. Give it a try, then - impress me.
Zethino: Close your eyes, little ones. Be still as stone to earth. And remember to breathe.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Players close their eyes, when they open them, they are somewhere like the meadow with daisy, or the waterfall from SH's romance. Zethino is a disembodied voice.

Extreme close-up on the eyes of player to help with the transition

Extreme close-up on the eyes of player to help with the transition
Zethino: Ah. Glorious. Your bond is sweeter than nature's dew. I see you. Know you. But do you know one another?
Zethino: Shadowheart: an endless storm surges behind sharp eyes.
Zethino: Listen. Think. From where does Shadowheart draw comfort on a cold, dark night?
Player: Judging others.
Shadowheart: I see. Are you sure you don't want to quit while you're behind?
NodeContext: Unimpressed deadpan (the player guessed a 'know your spouse' carnival game question incorrectly)
Zethino: Your bond tears but it does not break - have hope.
Zethino: The heart craves comfort, but needs respect. How does one earn the dark-haired maiden's respect?
Player: Farting on a Selûnite.
Shadowheart: I would never!
NodeContext: Mortified
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Player takes a second step, moving even closer to the center for the trunk to the companion.
Zethino: The sweetest loves dance lightly on the tongue. But now we must dig deeper. Into the most painful reaches of the spirit.
Zethino: Shame sits in the soul of all - to tame it, we must name it. Shadowheart - what is her deepest shame?
Player: Her hair.

He Who Was: The air stirs in trepidation - you have the ledger.
Player: Here - take it.
He Who Was: We have it - her lies, her guilt. Madeline reported her friends to a Dark Justiciar and fled when they were butchered.
He Who Was: Well, she flees no more. I will be the conduit for Madeline's spirit. I will force her to face trial.
He Who Was: And you will be the judge. Make her beg, make her suffer.

He Who Was: The raven was right, we were fated to meet. Break her, my friend - most thoroughly.

Player: You 'didn't mean' to kill your friends? How laughable.

Madeline: I said it didn't mean nothin', that Ben n' Marc were just drunk n' whining.

Madeline: The Dark Justiciar said to report everythin', big or small. She ain't the type you say no to.
Madeline: She gave 'em a dagger each, and told 'em to press it against their stomachs.
Madeline: On the count of three, to 'start stabbin', and not to stop 'til she said so.
Madeline: She never said stop. I'd do anything to take it back. Anything.

Halsin: Hmmm... that looks very alien. As alien as the mind flayers. They do not belong on this world.

Halsin: I've been studying these parasites for a while now. Ever since I discovered these so-called True Souls are infected with them.
Halsin: Someone is using very powerful magic to modify these tadpoles. They are using them to exert control over the infected.
Halsin: I'm sorry to say, I can't undo that magic, which means I can't cure you. But that doesn't mean I can't help.
Halsin: I didn't find what I came here for - a way to remove the tadpoles - but I found the next best thing. I found out where they come from.
Halsin: That must be where these enchantments are placed on them, and it's where you'll find your cure.
Player: How did you come to study mind flayer parasites?
Halsin: A drow forced me to defend myself. Afterwards, I was able to study the parasite that slithered out of the corpse, see what drives these 'True Souls'.
Halsin: I had no idea anyone beyond their ranks was infected. You have my sincere sympathies.
Player: This magic you mentioned - it isn't normal for these parasites?
Player: What should I do?
Halsin: I overheard that the cultists are sending all of their captives to Moonrise Towers.
Halsin: Innocents go in, True Souls come out. Given that all of these True Souls are infected, it has to be the source of this magic.
Halsin: If you want to find a cure, you must head there and discover how the tadpoles are being manipulated.
Player: Altered parasites? A cure at Moonrise Towers, maybe? Sounds like guesswork at best.
Halsin: I'm as certain as I can be. If you have a better alternative, I won't stop you.
Halsin: I can't stop you, in fact. Which brings me to my next problem...
Halsin: I've no right to ask more of you... but if you could help me, I'd be free to join your journey to Moonrise.
Halsin: I cannot allow these butchers to threaten my grove. The natural order must be protected.
Player: Kagha is dead. She was swayed by Shadow Druids. I had no choice.
Halsin: Kagha... This is my fault - I was her teacher. I will mourn her when I can.
Halsin: But there are other matters to attend to before that.
Halsin: Chaos is welcome, in doses; it helps keep balance. But this is too much - this is unnatural.
Halsin: Help me kill the leaders of this horde, save my grove. Then I will help you.

Halsin: Three deaths could win us peace: the drow Minthara, the hobgoblin Dror Ragzlin, and that perversion of a priestess, Gut.
Halsin: They are the ones holding these parasites together. Remove them and nature will cure itself.
Player: You ask too much of me. I can't help you.

Balthazar: Ah, the interloper - and in one piece as well. Not an entirely unpromising specimen, for one naturally-born.
NodeContext: Begrudging and largely hostile, but with a hint of appreciation for the player's skill in actually making it this far.
Balthazar: Not just any True Soul would have succeeded in following my path through this place. You should be pleased.
Balthazar: I take it the breaking of my skeletons was an accident - the living are so clumsy, after all.
Player: I'm pleased to be of service, Balthazar.
Balthazar: Perhaps you can prove to me that you're more useful alive than dead. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Balthazar: But you're here now, and I may be able to put those limbs to work. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Player: Something called the Nightsong. Your notes were very interesting.
Player: Yet you seem no closer to retrieving the Nightsong? I read your notes - very interesting.
Balthazar: Interesting, and private. Give me one reason why I shouldn't have my creations kill you right now, thief.
Player: You're hiding from shadows - literally. Don't make threats you can't back up.
Balthazar: ...Fine. I'll forgive your transgressions this time - there are much grander things at stake.
NodeContext: A pause before 'fine' - weighing up the player's fate.
Balthazar: The Nightsong is my finest creation - if I never exceed myself, I will still die happy. Not that I ever intend to do something as gauche as truly dying, of course.
Balthazar: Now, given your prying nature, I have work for you, as a scout.
Balthazar: The Nightsong lends the General his strength, his invulnerability. It must be recovered, before his enemies attempt to exploit it.
Player: You need my help?
Balthazar: I do not need you, or your help. But you are here in spite of that, so I may as well make use of you.
Balthazar: The Nightsong is close, but the way is barred and Shar's dead are... uncooperative. Clear the path for me - by blade, cunning, or whatever it takes.
Balthazar: I will remain here until you have succeeded, or fallen.
Shadowheart: I'd trust this gasbag about as far as I can throw him - which isn't far. But perhaps better to play along, for now.
Player: You have resources to spare - give me something to aid my search.
Balthazar: Fine. I will assign Flesh to aid you on your way. Ring this bell...
Balthazar: ...and he will come.
Balthazar: My brother is no intellectual powerhouse, but he is strong, loyal and punctual. Should a fight turn against you, remember the bell.
Player: Keep it - this is your problem, not mine.
Balthazar: This is not a problem - it is an opportunity. And it is not a choice either - you will obey.
Player: Fine. I'll see what I can do.
Player: I'll see what I can do.

Abdirak: Exactly, pain is an intimate thing. It should be delivered with a loving and measured hand.
Abdirak: But trying to discuss such subtleties with these creatures is simply...
Abdirak: Forgive me, but that look in your eyes - something terrible has happened to you.
Player: I'm trying to resist my drive to do harm, but it's very difficult.
Abdirak: Do not be ashamed, child. What I see in your eyes, in your soul, is only natural.
Abdirak: We've all suffered in these dark times. It is little wonder you bear scars of pain and anguish.
Abdirak: Please let me alleviate this pain.
Player: And how would you do that?
Abdirak: As the Maiden of Pain, the goddess Loviatar, teaches us...
Abdirak: ...through penance - administered by my skilled hand.
Abdirak: My work can grant peace and serenity - the likes of which few experience. It will be worth it - I promise.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: He gestures to the table, where a selection of weapons lays ready. The priest should look very sincere in this scene. He genuinely
thinks he's helping you.
thinks he's helping you.
Gale: Your hide, your choice. Not quite my cup of tea though.
Player: All right, why not?
Abdirak: Oh, I have something exquisite in mind.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeon’s voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar.
Malus Thorm: See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy.
Malus Thorm: Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the human’s belly, but it’s a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace.
Malus Thorm: Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver.
Malus Thorm: Come. Step forward. I can see the love of Shar darken your eyes. Be welcome.
Player: May Shar guide your blessing hands.
Malus Thorm: And the rough vessels that are yours.
Malus Thorm: Tell me, what is the guiding principle of the goddess?
Player: Secrecy.
Malus Thorm: I profess there is another more profound.
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly.
Malus Thorm: It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Karlach: What the fuck is this loon talking about.
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being?
Malus Thorm: If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: You are well on your way. But one white orb disfigures you still. Let us finish the cure.
Malus Thorm: We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.
Player: The sisters aren't ready. They'll make me sick instead of curing me.
Malus Thorm: Their incisions are, as yet, still streaked with imprecision - that much I must concede.
Malus Thorm: How to steady their hands, I wonder.
Player: Sparring is vital to progress. Have them practice on each other.
Player: Why not have them hone their skills on each other?
Malus Thorm: Yes... For are we not all in need of a cure?

Araj Oblodra: It's not for sale, but it's yours if you bite me.

Havkelaag: Ah, a surface dweller.
Havkelaag: You find yourself in the cradle of all knowledge relating to the Underdark: the Society of Brilliance.
Havkelaag: Tell me, what can the Society do for you?
Player: I carry an unhatched githyanki egg. Would you be interested in studying it?
Havkelaag: A githyanki egg? What a fortuitous turn of events. I've been attempting to get my hands on one for some time now.
Havkelaag: Would you consider parting with it? The Society's coffers are deep enough to cover any expenses accrued in its retrieval, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: Chk. Don't you dare consider it.
Player: What are you going to do with it?
Havkelaag: Study it, of course. The githyanki have been a source of great debate in the Society's circles in recent months.
Havkelaag: You yourself have no doubt experienced the prejudice of those who assume that, as beings of the Underdark, we are inherently evil.
Havkelaag: The githyanki face similar prejudice, but I believe, if hatched in a less violent, more intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome its evil predispositions.
Havkelaag: I believe that, if hatched in a morally sound, intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome the evil predisposition its githyanki nature bestows.
Player: You assume my people are evil, yet your research is built on sheer superstition.
Havkelaag: Enough of your kind have wreaked destruction on this plane for me to be confident in my assertion.
Havkelaag: When I have a suitable sample for my study, I will, however, prove that the effects of their biological inclination are reversible.
Havkelaag: Once out of the shell, I plan to take a twofold approach:
Havkelaag: The enforced repetition of sound moral principles from the Ptarian code, alongside a series of psionic pulses administered to the cerebral tissue.
Havkelaag: Assuming I can accelerate its growth, I should have conclusive findings within a year or two at the most.
Player: That kind of indoctrination and time-forced nurture violates the natural order. It invalidates the whole experiment.
Havkelaag: I won't bother to argue with you. An arboreal shaman can't be expected to understand the rigorous protocols of theoretical research.
Havkelaag: My findings could change the perception of githyanki and the peoples of the Underdark for generations to come.
Player: Sounds pointless. Public opinion will hardly be swayed by such a small experiment.
Havkelaag: Not at first. But if the experiment proves successful, it must be repeated. Only then will we know if the findings are to be trusted.
Havkelaag: Now, I'm eager to get started, so will you sell me the egg? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: A gith hatchling is not a lab rat! This shka'keth should be bled dry for the mere suggestion.
Player: This experiment is barbaric. You're never getting the egg.

Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeon’s voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar.
Malus Thorm: See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy.
Malus Thorm: Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the human’s belly, but it’s a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace.
Malus Thorm: Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver.
Malus Thorm: Come. Step forward. I can see the love of Shar darken your eyes. Be welcome.
Player: May Shar guide your blessing hands.
Malus Thorm: And the rough vessels that are yours.
Malus Thorm: Tell me, what is the guiding principle of the goddess?
Player: Forgetfulness.
Malus Thorm: I profess there is another more profound.
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly.
Malus Thorm: It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Wyll: Hells. Only a monster would inflict misery and call it medicine.
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being?
Malus Thorm: If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: But you: look how the succour of Shar eludes you. See how painfully present you remain...
Malus Thorm: We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.
Player: Your subject is tainted. Shar's succour must only be granted to the willing.
Malus Thorm: Hmmm. 'Only the willing may know the Lady's embrace.' You know her teachings well.
Malus Thorm: And yet, these sisters must exercise their gifts, for the art of absence lies in its execution.
Malus Thorm: How to proceed, I wonder.
Player: Sparring is vital to progress. Have them practice on each other.
Player: Why not have them hone their skills on each other?
Malus Thorm: Yes... For are we not all in need of a cure?
Malus Thorm: The scalpel does not discriminate. Let each and every one of you partake in its soothing journey.
Malus Thorm: Absence, sisters. Acquaint yourselves.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) Screaming and slashing, the sisters brutally murder each other.
Malus Thorm: It is a proud moment when one sees one's teachings so lovingly taken to heart.
Malus Thorm: You are to be commended for their graduation - rewarded with the promised cure.
Malus Thorm: Come, I will acquaint you with the Lady's dark-fingered embrace.
Player: You do me an honour, but I am not worthy. Show me the way of Shar - I beg of you.
Player: I would rather acquaint myself - if you show me how.
Malus Thorm: Your diligence is exemplary. Very well: your own scalpel you will be.

Chessa: You better watch out, our parents will be here soon. And when they find you, they'll - urgh.
Narrator: *You know that pain well. She's feeling the same hunger that's plagued you for two hundred years.*
Chessa: What? What are you looking at?
Player: Your parents aren't coming. But I am. I'm here to save you.
Chessa: You? It can't be...
Chessa: You're the one that did this to us. You're the one that took us, and offered us up to be Cazador's spawns.
Player: I regret it. I regret everything.
Chessa: We were supposed to be hunters. We spent our whole lives training, studying... You were the one we were supposed to kill!
Chessa: Now we're no better than you. Worse. At least you get to roam free.
Player: Quit whining. You're a vampire spawn now. That's much better than being human.
Chessa: How? How is it better?
Player: You'll never die.
Chessa: That's not a good thing. That was going to be our way out of this.
Chessa: As long as we're here, as long as Cazador's alive, we're - stuck.
Chessa: We thought we'd figured it out at first - we could just stake ourselves with sharp twigs from the gutter and be done with it. But - it's harder than it looks.
Chessa: Even when we managed it, all it did was paralyse us. We tried twice each, just to be sure.
Player: I'm here to free you.
Chessa: You want to free us?
Chessa: Why...?
Player: Simple. I save your lives, your parents stop hunting me.
Chessa: Self-preservation - that actually makes sense. If you'd said anything else, I'd have struggled to believe you.
Chessa: So what are you waiting for? Let us out!
Player: I'll free you once I have Cazador's staff.

Zevlor: We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.

Wyll: Zevlor.
Zevlor: By Dhelt's virtue, the Blade of Frontiers? What's happened, Wyll?
Wyll: I paid the price of angering the wrong devil.
Zevlor: Believe me - I understand better than most.
Narrator: *A moment passes as Zevlor contemplates Wyll's words. He then turns his attentions to you.*
Zevlor: I'd advise you to settle your affairs here quickly.
Zevlor: Once the druids complete their ritual, we'll be sharing the road with goblins once again.
Zevlor: Unless you've reconsidered speaking to them for us? Kagha might listen to you.
Player: I want to discuss something else.
Zevlor: What is it?
Player: I'm looking for a man named Zorru.
Zevlor: You'll find him in camp. What do you want with him?
Player: That is between the two of us.
Zevlor: You'll find him in the caves. But I warn you not to start trouble. There's already enough going.
Zevlor: Whatever your business here, I'd see to it quickly - the druids are forcing everyone out.
Zevlor: This latest attack will only strengthen their resolve.
Player: Outsiders, perhaps. But not me.
Zevlor: Lucky you.
Zevlor: There have been several attacks by different monsters. The druids blame us 'outsiders' for drawing them here. Nobody's welcome anymore.
Zevlor: They've started a ritual to cut the grove off from the world outside.
Zevlor: We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: What brought you here?
Zevlor: We're refugees from Elturel - we took shelter here after goblins and gnolls attacked us on the road.
Zevlor: We were bound for Baldur's Gate, and it was too late to turn back. Elturel had no place for tieflings after the Descent.
Karlach: Gods, these are those tiefs? Their whole city was dragged into Avernus for a while. Zariel was delighted. When they made it back out, I'd hoped they got their happy ending.
Narrator: *'The Descent' - an infernal conspiracy that had seen the entire city of Elturel briefly dragged to the Hells.*
Player: Maybe your people should have stayed in Hell.
Zevlor: It seems you're of a mind with our hosts here. But their ritual will force you out, too.
Zevlor: We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: This ritual - is there no way to convince the druids to stop it?
Zevlor: I've tried. Kagha - their new First Druid - won't see me.
Zevlor: You, though... I know it's not your business, but she owes you for saving this place.
Zevlor: Perhaps you could persuade her. For more time to prepare, if nothing else.
Player: I'm sorry. I've got my own problems.

He Who Was: The air stirs in trepidation - you have the ledger.
Player: Here - take it.
He Who Was: We have it - her lies, her guilt. Madeline reported her friends to a Dark Justiciar and fled when they were butchered.
He Who Was: Well, she flees no more. I will be the conduit for Madeline's spirit. I will force her to face trial.
He Who Was: And you will be the judge. Make her beg, make her suffer.
Player: When punishment is needed, my hand will not shy from the blade.
He Who Was: The raven was right, we were fated to meet. Break her, my friend - most thoroughly.
He Who Was: Witness her.
NodeContext: low, excited voice. Eyes roll back in his head as he looks up - body jerking. Falls to his knees.
Madeline: You! He said I was gonna be punished, that you'd be the judge. But I didn't mean to hurt anyone!
Player: You 'didn't mean' to kill your friends? How laughable.
Lae'zel: Yes - how laughable. You're above such things as the killing urge.
Madeline: I said it didn't mean nothin', that Ben n' Marc were just drunk n' whining.
Madeline: The Dark Justiciar promised she was gonna chat with 'em. She promised.
Player: Don't blame others for what you did.
Madeline: You didn't see it. Didn't see what the Dark Justiciar did.
Madeline: She gave 'em a dagger each, and told 'em to press it against their stomachs.
Madeline: On the count of three, to 'start stabbin', and not to stop 'til she said so.
Madeline: She never said stop. I'd do anything to take it back. Anything.
Player: Stab yourself. Rip your stomach open. Feel the pain of your friends - only then will you be free.
Player: Anything? Then hurt yourself as Ben and Marc did - stab yourself.
Madeline: Like... this?
NodeContext: Madeline draws a blade from behind her and holds it in front of her stomach, blade pointed towards her stomach. She is utterly terrified (pose like seppuku)
Player: Start stabbing, and don't stop until I say so.
Madeline: Ah! I'm sorry.
NodeContext: Ah! is a noise of pain as she stabs herself in the stomach and then pulls out the knife. 'I'm sorry' is said in clear pain.
Madeline: Argh. I'm so sorry.
NodeContext: stabs herself again on 'Argh', noise of pain. I'm so so sorry is half crying as she's in agony.
Player: Keep going.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Wyll enters camp. A diabolical circle draws itself onto the ground in front of Wyll, and Mizora in devil form rises from it.
Mizora: Sorores surge. Testis esto pacti mei.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Two more diabolical circles form, and a female devil rises from each.
Narrator: *You've heard of such devils - Sisters of Justice, adjudicators of diabolical contracts and bargains.*
Karlach: Holy fucking hells.
Wyll: What are you up to, Mizora?
Mizora: I come to bargain. The Hells demand witness.
Mizora: Your father is dead, Wyll. The Dead Three have claimed their prize.
Wyll: It can't be. I don't believe you.
Mizora: I've no reason to lie. He's gone - for good, some might say. But not every death is forever.
Arbiter Cirrus: Infernus contractus te vocamus. Infernus contractus te vocamus. Infernus contractus te vocamus.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: A contract appears in the air, glowing. It is Wyll's contract.
Wyll: Then break it now, Mizora. I don't need to wait six months.
Mizora: No contract is ended without sacrifice. A cost must be paid.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Flames ignite Mizora and her two companions. Mizora's voice echos outward as if amplified by the Hells themselves.
Mizora: Wyll Ravengard. A choice is before you.
Mizora: Option one. I show you the way to your father. I guarantee him no harm except that from you and your allies. And you pledge your soul to me and the archdevil Zariel in a pact eternal.
Mizora: Option two. I break your pact, and you are freed from your duty. Your father dies by his enemy's hand, and Baldur's Gate loses its greatest champion.
Mizora: Name your sacrifice.
Karlach: Bloody Zariel. I won't let her take Wyll!
Mizora: Silence, Karlach!
Wyll: Mizora, you arsehole.
Mizora: Choose.
Player: Do the right thing. Give your soul so that your father can live.

Havkelaag: I say - that wasn't a githyanki egg you were fiddling around with, was it?
Havkelaag: How would you like to sell it to the Society of Brilliance? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Havkelaag: Would you consider parting with it? The Society's coffers are deep enough to cover any expenses accrued in its retrieval, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: Chk. Don't you dare consider it.
Player: What are you going to do with it?
Havkelaag: Study it, of course. The githyanki have been a source of great debate in the Society's circles in recent months.
Havkelaag: You are no doubt aware that citizens of the Underdark are held in great suspicion by those who live above ground. Many believe us to be 'evil'.
Havkelaag: The githyanki face similar prejudice, but I believe, if hatched in a less violent, more intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome its evil predispositions.
Havkelaag: I believe that, if hatched in a morally sound, intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome the evil predisposition its githyanki nature bestows.
Player: What does this 'intellectually stimulating' upbringing look like?
Havkelaag: In the literal sense, I will need to induce the egg to hatch via the application of certain currents to the creature inside.
Havkelaag: Once out of the shell, I plan to take a twofold approach:
Havkelaag: The enforced repetition of sound moral principles from the Ptarian code, alongside a series of psionic pulses administered to the cerebral tissue.
Havkelaag: Assuming I can accelerate its growth, I should have conclusive findings within a year or two at the most.
Player: Why follow the dogma of a draconic god?
Havkelaag: In my years of study, they're the closest I've found to moral perfection. Only under such rigorous 'goodness' will the subject stand a chance of being cured.
Havkelaag: My findings could change the perception of githyanki and the peoples of the Underdark for generations to come.
Player: No benefit could justify you inflicting such cruelty.
Havkelaag: Rigorous experimental methods demand we do not indulge our own emotional responses in the application of discomfort to our subjects.
Havkelaag: Only by the full, uninhibited application of psionic stimuli will we have a true measure of whether the child's innate evil has been cured.
Havkelaag: Now, I'm eager to get started, so will you sell me the egg? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: A gith hatchling is not a lab rat! This shka'keth should be bled dry for the mere suggestion.
Player: This experiment is barbaric. You're never getting the egg.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeon’s voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar.
Malus Thorm: See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy.
Malus Thorm: Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the human’s belly, but it’s a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace.
Malus Thorm: Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver.
Malus Thorm: Come. Step forward. I can see the love of Shar darken your eyes. Be welcome.
Player: May Shar guide your blessing hands.
Malus Thorm: And the rough vessels that are yours.
Malus Thorm: Tell me, what is the guiding principle of the goddess?
Player: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Precisely.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly.
Malus Thorm: It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Astarion: He's just like Cazador - utterly insane.
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being?
Malus Thorm: If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: You are well on your way. But one white orb disfigures you still. Let us finish the cure.
Malus Thorm: We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.
Player: The sisters aren't ready. They'll make me sick instead of curing me.
Malus Thorm: Their incisions are, as yet, still streaked with imprecision - that much I must concede.
Malus Thorm: How to steady their hands, I wonder.
Player: Why not have them hone their skills on each other?
Malus Thorm: Yes... For are we not all in need of a cure?
Malus Thorm: The scalpel does not discriminate. Let each and every one of you partake in its soothing journey.
Malus Thorm: Absence, sisters. Acquaint yourselves.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) Screaming and slashing, the sisters brutally murder each other.
Malus Thorm: It is a proud moment when one sees one's teachings so lovingly taken to heart.
Malus Thorm: You are to be commended for their graduation - rewarded with the promised cure.
Malus Thorm: Come, I will acquaint you with the Lady's dark-fingered embrace.
Player: My magic has blinded me - I see now that Shar is the only path. Show me how - I beg of you.
Player: I would rather acquaint myself - if you show me how.
Malus Thorm: Your diligence is exemplary. Very well: your own scalpel you will be.

Gandrel: You've tracked me down again, my friend. Would that I had as much luck with the beast I'm hunting.
Astarion: You're a monster hunter? I'm surprised - I thought all Gur were vagrant cut-throats.
Player: Pardon, but who - or what - is a Gur?
Gandrel: A mystical and dangerous people, we travel the land, never settling in one place.
Gandrel: We steal your chickens, curse your crops, seduce your daughters - your friend here has heard it all, I'm sure.
Gandrel: I wish I had half the power settled folk think my people possess. Alas, I am a simple wanderer.
Gandrel: A simple wanderer and monster hunter. But I'm no witchdoctor or cut-throat.
Player: I assume you want to kill the hag?
Astarion: Or to make a deal with her. Probably think you can outfox the old dear.
Gandrel: Right, but very wrong. My prey is a vampire spawn - much less impressive than the beast that lives here.
Gandrel: I fear he's gone to ground. I hoped the hag of these lands could help me flush him out, but it seems she is no more.
Astarion: A vampire spawn? Why?
Player: Everything all right?
Astarion: Yes, yes, fine. It's just - specific. Why not kill the gnolls or goblins rampaging around here?
Gandrel: It is a sacred mission from the head of my tribe. She sent me here to capture the beast and return it to her.
Astarion: Capture? And bring it where?
Gandrel: Baldur's Gate. My people wait for me there.
Player: Say nothing.
Astarion: I've crossed paths with your people before, you know.
Astarion: It wasn't a good experience.
NodeContext: You've just stabbed your nemesis in the eye with a dagger. You pull it loose as he slumps to the floor. This line follows on from 'I've crossed paths with his people before' -> (stabbing) -> it wasn't a good experience.
Player: ...Tell me you had a good reason for that.
Astarion: He was spinning a tale, and you were falling for it. Vampires? Sacred missions? Honestly.
Astarion: He would've followed us to camp and slit our throats in the night.
Astarion: Trust me, I did us a favour.
Player: Trust you? After that?

Zethino: You return, stira. Shall I look into your hearts, yours and your beloved's both, and see if your love will stand the test of time? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Zethino: You return, stira. I pray the hearts of you and your companion are ready - for love is a fragile blossom, and we will test its resilience. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Player: What do you say, Shadowheart? Do you want to try this?
Player: What do you say, Shadowheart?
Shadowheart: It can't hurt, I suppose - unless you embarrass me. Then you might find yourself hurting in a whole manner of ways.
Zethino: Close your eyes, little ones. Be still as stone to earth. And remember to breathe.
