[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeon’s voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar.
Malus Thorm: See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy.
Malus Thorm: Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the human’s belly, but it’s a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace.
Malus Thorm: Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver.
Malus Thorm: Come. Step forward. You are no sister, but that matters none. Every student is welcome.
Player: Just kill them already - all this torture is pointless.
Malus Thorm: Behold, sisters, the very face of ignorance - one who mistakes tenderness for torture.
Malus Thorm: Go on. Acquaint the face of ignorance with the true object of our studies.
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly.
Malus Thorm: It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Wyll: Hells. Only a monster would inflict misery and call it medicine.
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being?
Malus Thorm: If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: But you: look how the succour of Shar eludes you. See how painfully present you remain...
Malus Thorm: We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.
Player: The sisters aren't ready. They'll make me sick instead of curing me.
Malus Thorm: Their incisions are, as yet, still streaked with imprecision - that much I must concede.
Malus Thorm: How to steady their hands, I wonder.
Player: Sparring is vital to progress. Have them practice on each other.
Player: Why not have them hone their skills on each other?
Malus Thorm: Yes... For are we not all in need of a cure?
Malus Thorm: The scalpel does not discriminate. Let each and every one of you partake in its soothing journey.
Malus Thorm: Absence, sisters. Acquaint yourselves.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) Screaming and slashing, the sisters brutally murder each other.
Malus Thorm: It is a proud moment when one sees one's teachings so lovingly taken to heart.
Malus Thorm: You are to be commended for their graduation - rewarded with the promised cure.
Malus Thorm: Come, I will acquaint you with the Lady's dark-fingered embrace.
Player: I am but a fumbling squire before a master swordsman. Please, demonstrate so that I might learn.
Player: I would rather acquaint myself - if you show me how.
Malus Thorm: Your diligence is exemplary. Very well: your own scalpel you will be.

Kar'niss: Very well. If it is your will, they can have it.
NodeContext: Drider throws the Moonlantern to the ground in anger
Player: Good. You may go now.
Brawler Vez: ...Whatcha mean 'go'?
Kansif: We can't go without you - the shadows would tear us to pieces.
Kar'niss: This is not her Majesty's will.
Player: The Absolute wants you to go. Now!
Player: The Absolute has blessed you. You will be safe.
Kar'niss: If - if it is her majesty's will...
Kansif: You can't be serious. You know what's out there-
Kar'niss: IF IT IS HER MAJESTY'S WILL, THEN WE SHALL WALK!
Kar'niss: She will protect us. She - she must.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The HALF-ORC shoots you a dirty look, but follows the DRIDER into the darkness, along with the other cultists. There is silence for a beat before screams start to pierce the air. There is sound of a brief battle.

GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: It is so good to see you again! I can't tell you how glad I am that you didn't enter the House without me.
Player: Who are you?
Narrator: *The figure shimmers brightly. Your words seem to have piqued her curiosity.*
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: Who am I? It's my favourite question. I scream it into the dark while I sleep, and whisper it to my memories when I wake.
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: I'm the thing that kills you, and the only reason you're alive. Made by a promise, undone by the truth. A handshake, a hug, the first beat of a newborn's heart.
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: I am Hope. What little is left of her.
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: A GUTTERING CANDLE IN A UNIVERSE OF NIGHT
Karlach: Raphael's driven her mad. Poor soul.
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: I'm not much of a friend to anyone anymore. But I could use a friend myself. Do you want a friend to guide you through this madhouse?
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: Shhhtttt, I hear the jailor, it hears me. It'll call Raphael. Make every question count. Make some of them count twice.
Lae'zel: You must ask of the Orphic Hammer. Without it, the Prince of the Comet - and the githyanki people - remain forever chained.
: NodeContext: urgent hushing and frantically getting out all of her words as quickly as possible. She's hushing the player, even though she was the one speaking
Player: I need to find the Orphic Hammer. Can you help?
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: Hope can help. The Hammer is here, in this House - it's...
Narrator: *You hear a sound like the rattle of a chain, and an agonising scream in your head as Hope flickers from view momentarily.*
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: Shhhhttttt... Quiet... There it goes...
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: Everyone here is mad - even you, especially me - and that makes them dangerous. But it also makes them stupid.
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: I'll make you seem as ruined as the rest of the people here. A simple glamour to make you a terrible wretch.
NodeContext: very enthusiastic, casting a spell to disguise the player
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: Now whisper your questions, little wretch. But really quiet, and very clever. Concentrate.
Player: Speak quietly, and with reserve.
Player: Focus on speaking as quietly and calmly as possible.
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: Remember. Quiet as a mouse.
Player: Where will I find my contract?
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: THE SAME PLACE YOU'LL FIND YOUR SORRY LITTLE SOUL WHEN RAPHAEL RIPS IT OUT
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: The paper cage for your soul. Such a tiny thing, but it's one of his favourites.
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: In the Archive. Down the corridor, past the debtors. OH! The debtors. They won't like you.
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: But I like you. I know I do, I think I do, I hope I do. I just need to ask one question, and I'll know for sure.
Player: No. I'm not telling you anything.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Hide Marcus
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Isobel is standing on the balcony, bathed in a beam of moonlight piercing the darkness. Her hands are in a prayer position and she's chanting softly as the moonlight dances around her. She exhales, then inhales and breaths in tendrils of shadow, absorbing them. She swallows, then begins hacking coughing. The moonlight dissipates. She quickly goes from seeming like a divine spirit to a normal young woman.
Isobel: I didn't realise I had an audience.
Fist Marcus: Isobel. This is -
Isobel: A Sharran.
Narrator: *Isobel. The same name as Ketheric Thorm's daughter - the one whose sarcophagus you found empty in the family mausoleum.*
Player: Push your Urges down.
Player: Let's not let an ancient squabble interfere with the task at hand.
Isobel: Not as ancient as you think.
Isobel: Frankly, I'm surprised you're willing to help us. Your kind aren't known for their decency - particularly when a Sharran curse is our greatest obstacle.
Isobel: But if you are who I think you are, I'd be a fool to reject your help. The True Soul with... well, a soul. Imagine.
Player: I'm glad you've remembered who needs whose help here.
Isobel: Oh - aren't you looking for a protection spell?
Player: I need nothing from a Selûnite.
Isobel: But any others who travel with you may not agree. Do it for them at least - you will need all the help you can get out there.
Player: Ngh... it hurts...
Isobel: Well! If the Moonmaiden didn't strike me dead for blessing you, she must rather approve of this little alliance.
Isobel: This will block the lesser effects of the shadow curse, allowing you to traverse the darkness outside... should Shar's own protection falter, that is.
Isobel: Curious. Surely the Nightsinger could have shielded all her followers, and made this place her domain long ago... yet she only acts now, and aids you alone. I wonder why.
Player: The Dark Lady's works aren't for me to question.
Isobel: Mustn't question the great shadow mother, must we?
Isobel: I'll stop needling you, though. You have more important things to do, after all.
Player: I do, though I already have a Moonlantern.
Player: I already have a Moonlantern. I can safely travel the shadows.
Isobel: Well! Now you have two. Just in case.
Isobel: I wish you luck. The very best of it.
Player: Hold on - Marcus is a True Soul. He's here to kidnap you.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeon’s voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar.
Malus Thorm: See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy.
Malus Thorm: Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the human’s belly, but it’s a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace.
Malus Thorm: Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver.
Malus Thorm: Come. Step forward. You are no sister, but that matters none. Every student is welcome.
Player: Just kill them already - all this torture is pointless.
Malus Thorm: Behold, sisters, the very face of ignorance - one who mistakes tenderness for torture.
Malus Thorm: Go on. Acquaint the face of ignorance with the true object of our studies.
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly.
Malus Thorm: It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Lae'zel: Only a beast of a man toys with his victim. Entertaining, if not efficient.
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being?
Malus Thorm: If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: You are well on your way. But one white orb disfigures you still. Let us finish the cure.
Malus Thorm: We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.
Player: Your subject is tainted. Shar's succour must only be granted to the willing.
Malus Thorm: Hmmm. 'Only the willing may know the Lady's embrace.' You know her teachings well.
Malus Thorm: And yet, these sisters must exercise their gifts, for the art of absence lies in its execution.
Malus Thorm: How to proceed, I wonder.
Player: Practice - that's how I got good with a blade. They should spar each other.
Player: Why not have them hone their skills on each other?
Malus Thorm: Yes... For are we not all in need of a cure?

Halsin: Pardon the viscera. One should cherish all of nature's bounty... but goblin guts are quite far down the list.
NodeContext: Hint of wry humour, Introducing himself after transforming from an owlbear and killing several goblins.
Halsin: Not only do you speak with a bear, but you free it, too? A true friend of nature - or perhaps a lunatic.
Halsin: Either way, I owe thanks. I am the druid Halsin.
Player: Glad I could be of help.
Halsin: I must admit, I didn't expect anyone would come to my aid. Who in their right mind would infiltrate a goblin infested temple. Unless...
Halsin: ...Hrrm. That look in your eyes - I've seen it before. Are you feeling all right?
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Halsin raises a hand to your head, magically connecting with you (no contact). He gives an alarmed look - he knows what’s inside you
Halsin: Oak Father preserve you, child... You're infected, aren't you? The mind flayers' spawn.
Halsin: But... something's different. You're aware of the monster inside you. You don't bow to the Absolute, like the True Souls do...
Halsin: How is this possible...?
Player: I think this artefact has something to do with it.
Halsin: Hmmm... that looks very alien. As alien as the mind flayers. They do not belong on this world.
Halsin: You weren't speaking lightly when you said you needed help. Let me tell you what I know.
Halsin: I've been studying these parasites for a while now. Ever since I discovered these so-called True Souls are infected with them.
Halsin: Someone is using very powerful magic to modify these tadpoles. They are using them to exert control over the infected.
Halsin: I'm sorry to say, I can't undo that magic, which means I can't cure you. But that doesn't mean I can't help.
Halsin: I didn't find what I came here for - a way to remove the tadpoles - but I found the next best thing. I found out where they come from.
Halsin: That must be where these enchantments are placed on them, and it's where you'll find your cure.
Player: How did you come to study mind flayer parasites?
Halsin: A drow forced me to defend myself. Afterwards, I was able to study the parasite that slithered out of the corpse, see what drives these 'True Souls'.
Halsin: I had no idea anyone beyond their ranks was infected. You have my sincere sympathies.
Player: What should I do?
Halsin: I overheard that the cultists are sending all of their captives to Moonrise Towers.
Halsin: Innocents go in, True Souls come out. Given that all of these True Souls are infected, it has to be the source of this magic.
Halsin: If you want to find a cure, you must head there and discover how the tadpoles are being manipulated.
Player: At least I know what to do now. Thank you.
Halsin: Wait - I could help you find a cure... but I need to settle matters here first.
Halsin: I've no right to ask more of you... but if you could help me, I'd be free to join your journey to Moonrise.
Halsin: I cannot allow these butchers to threaten my grove. The natural order must be protected.
Player: Kagha was swayed by Shadow Druids. She nearly sealed the grove.
Halsin: Kagha... I should have suspected she'd take things too far. I'll deal with her when I can.
Halsin: But there are other matters to attend to before that.
Halsin: Chaos is welcome, in doses; it helps keep balance. But this is too much - this is unnatural.
Halsin: Help me kill the leaders of this horde, save my grove. Then I will help you.

Halsin: Three deaths could win us peace: the drow Minthara, the hobgoblin Dror Ragzlin, and that perversion of a priestess, Gut.
Halsin: They are the ones holding these parasites together. Remove them and nature will cure itself.
Player: Having a shapeshifting bear-druid at my side might make things easier.
Player: Follow me, then. Your bear form may prove useful.
Halsin: Be warned - my presence could make things more difficult... I can only restrain my bear form so much. I won't be able to help but attack goblins.
Halsin: If I join you, we'll likely have to slaughter this entire place. You may want to use discretion when approaching the goblin leaders.
Player: Stay here.

Narrator: *The device is strange, made of taut flesh and pockmarked metal. It waits for something.*
Lae'zel: The zaith'isk. Vlaakith's purity, distilled. My duty. My right.
Player: Stand back. I'm going first.
Lae'zel: I will not. I gave you my might. You will respect my charge.
Player: Very well. Step forward and be cleansed.
Lae'zel: Praise Vlaakith, let it be done.
Ghustil Stornugoss: Sit, child. Let the zaith'isk end your suffering.

Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace.

Lorroakan: Mark my words: the Nightsong is mine. With or without your help, she will ascend to her grand fate here, in this tower.
Lorroakan: You can get very rich along the way, or let someone else take what's rightfully yours. Choose wisely.
Player: You must be the wizard Lorroakan. I've heard a great deal about you.
Lorroakan: My - could it be? Gale of Waterdeep, here in my tower. I'm surprised you dare show your face after Mystra cast you on the scrap heap.
Lorroakan: Well don't stand on ceremony - out with it.
Player: I seek a certain rare tome - concerning Karsus.
Lorroakan: You're quite in luck, then - see Tolna downstairs. One such tome is amongst our rarest books.
Lorroakan: But enough of dusty history - I look to the future.
Lorroakan: You know I seek the Nightsong. Do you have it or not?
Player: What do you want with her?
Lorroakan: 'She'. Then you do know her. You've been to Shar's temple. To the Shadowfell. You've looked upon the Nightsong's face.
Lorroakan: Tell me - and choose your next words carefully - where is she now?

Lorroakan: It can bind a celestial to the wearer's service with a snap of the fingers.
Lorroakan: And this? This can keep her in place. Forever.

Player: A clever contraption. Let me guess: like Ketheric Thorm before you, you wish to become immortal.

Lorroakan: I serve no god but that which stares back at me in the mirror.
Lorroakan: The Nightsong will be put to a grand purpose: equalising man and god. Whoever helps me attain that which I seek will be greatly rewarded.

Lorroakan: I intend to achieve greatness. And I intend to do it for a long, long, long time.
Lorroakan: When I succeed, I may look favourably upon you. If you are a friend along the way, that is.
Lorroakan: And this? This can keep her in place. Forever.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeon’s voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar.
Malus Thorm: See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy.
Malus Thorm: Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the human’s belly, but it’s a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace.
Malus Thorm: Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver.
Malus Thorm: Come. Step forward. You are no sister, but that matters none. Every student is welcome.
Player: Just kill them already - all this torture is pointless.
Malus Thorm: Behold, sisters, the very face of ignorance - one who mistakes tenderness for torture.
Malus Thorm: Go on. Acquaint the face of ignorance with the true object of our studies.
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly.
Malus Thorm: It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Shadowheart: A stinging truth - but a truth nonetheless.
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being?
Malus Thorm: If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: But you: look how the succour of Shar eludes even you, one who walks faithfully in her shadow. See how painfully present you remain...
Malus Thorm: We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.
Player: Their blades are uneven. Efficient surgery will require further training.
Malus Thorm: Their incisions are, as yet, still streaked with imprecision - that much I must concede.
Malus Thorm: How to steady their hands, I wonder.
Player: I take joy in performing with a master of my craft - I'm sure the sisters are the same. Why don't you volunteer?
Player: In my years of study, I have found no better teacher than example. Perhaps you could volunteer?
Malus Thorm: I see now. By example I must edify and quell the light that blinds us.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeon’s voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar.
Malus Thorm: See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy.
Malus Thorm: Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the human’s belly, but it’s a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace.
Malus Thorm: Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver.
Malus Thorm: Come. Step forward. I can see the love of Shar darken your eyes. Be welcome.
Player: What lesson are you teaching these sisters?
Malus Thorm: The crux of our worship.
Malus Thorm: Tell me, what is the guiding principle of the goddess?
Player: Darkness.
Malus Thorm: I profess there is another more profound.
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly.
Malus Thorm: It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Shadowheart: A stinging truth - but a truth nonetheless.
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being?

Player: You're hiding from shadows - literally. Don't make threats you can't back up.

Balthazar: The Nightsong is my finest creation - if I never exceed myself, I will still die happy. Not that I ever intend to do something as gauche as truly dying, of course.
Balthazar: Now, given your prying nature, I have work for you, as a scout.
Balthazar: The Nightsong lends the General his strength, his invulnerability. It must be recovered, before his enemies attempt to exploit it.
Player: Sounds like you've good reason to be proud of the Nightsong - tell me more.

Balthazar: Words - even my words - are woefully insufficient. When you see for yourself, you will understand.
Player: What do you need me to do?

Balthazar: The relic is close, but the way is barred and Shar's dead are... uncooperative. Clear the path for me - by blade, cunning, or whatever it takes.
Balthazar: I will remain here until you have succeeded, or fallen.
Shadowheart: I'd trust this gasbag about as far as I can throw him - which isn't far. But perhaps better to play along, for now.

Balthazar: Fine. I will assign Flesh to aid you on your way. Ring this bell...

Mizora: Option two. I break your pact, and you are freed from your duty. Your father dies by his enemy's hand, and Baldur's Gate loses its greatest champion.

Mizora: Choose.
Player: Do the right thing. Give your soul so that your father can live.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeon’s voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar.
Malus Thorm: See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy.
Malus Thorm: Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the human’s belly, but it’s a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace.
Malus Thorm: Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver.
Malus Thorm: Come. Step forward. I can see the love of Shar darken your eyes. Be welcome.
Player: May Shar guide your blessing hands.
Malus Thorm: And the rough vessels that are yours.
Malus Thorm: Tell me, what is the guiding principle of the goddess?
Player: Forgetfulness.
Malus Thorm: I profess there is another more profound.
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly.
Malus Thorm: It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Wyll: Hells. Only a monster would inflict misery and call it medicine.
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being?
Malus Thorm: If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: But you: look how the succour of Shar eludes even you, one who walks faithfully in her shadow. See how painfully present you remain...
Malus Thorm: We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.
Player: Their blades are uneven. Efficient surgery will require further training.
Malus Thorm: Their incisions are, as yet, still streaked with imprecision - that much I must concede.
Malus Thorm: How to steady their hands, I wonder.
Player: When the fist trembles, sometimes another is needed to steady it. A good master would volunteer themselves.
Player: In my years of study, I have found no better teacher than example. Perhaps you could volunteer?
Malus Thorm: I see now. By example I must edify and quell the light that blinds us.

GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: It is so good to see you again! I can't tell you how glad I am that you didn't enter the House without me.

GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: Who am I? It's my favourite question. I scream it into the dark while I sleep, and whisper it to my memories when I wake.
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: I'm the thing that kills you, and the only reason you're alive. Made by a promise, undone by the truth. A handshake, a hug, the first beat of a newborn's heart.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Isobel is standing on the balcony, bathed in a beam of moonlight piercing the darkness. Her hands are in a prayer position and she's chanting softly as the moonlight dances around her. She exhales, then inhales and breaths in tendrils of shadow, absorbing them. She swallows, then begins hacking coughing. The moonlight dissipates. She quickly goes from seeming like a divine spirit to a normal young woman.
Isobel: I didn't realise I had an audience.
Fist Marcus: Isobel. This is -
Isobel: A Sharran.
Narrator: *Isobel. The same name as Ketheric Thorm's daughter - the one whose sarcophagus you found empty in the family mausoleum.*
Player: Push your Urges down.
Player: Isobel - Isobel Thorm?
Narrator: *Her breath catches; you notice a barely-perceptible shudder run through her body.*
Isobel: An unfortunate coincidence. I hope never to meet the wicked man who haemorrhaged shadows over this peaceful village. I've heard you might be the person to stop him.
Isobel: A True Soul with a soul. Imagine.
Isobel: But if you are who I think you are, I'd be a fool to reject your help. The True Soul with... well, a soul. Imagine.
Player: I won't be spoken to like that by a Selûnite.
Isobel: We've both got a bitter pill to swallow. When this is all over, we can spit it back out.
Isobel: You'll be needing the protection spell, I presume?
Isobel: Oh - aren't you looking for a protection spell?
Player: I am already protected. My Lady shields me from the curse.
Isobel: For now, perhaps. But Shar can be fickle, and her love can prove fleeting. Do not turn your back on an advantage you may need... even a Selûnite one.
Isobel: If nothing else, it can aid any companions who travel with you - somehow I doubt Shar's largesse was extended to them.
Player: It was nothing. Put it out of your mind.
Narrator: *But was it truly nothing? The pain gripped you tight, robbing you of all composure for a moment...*
Isobel: Well! If the Moonmaiden didn't strike me dead for blessing you, she must rather approve of this little alliance.
Isobel: This will block the lesser effects of the shadow curse, allowing you to traverse the darkness outside... should Shar's own protection falter, that is.
Isobel: Curious. Surely the Nightsinger could have shielded all her followers, and made this place her domain long ago... yet she only acts now, and aids you alone. I wonder why.
Player: The Dark Lady's works aren't for me to question.
Isobel: Mustn't question the great shadow mother, must we?
Isobel: I'll stop needling you, though. You have more important things to do, after all.
Player: I've already been to Moonrise, but I have more work to do indeed.
Isobel: I imagine so, if Jaheira hasn't gone tearing off into the night.
Player: Wait - Marcus is a True Soul, you know. And not the good kind, like me.

Oyster Boy Dringo: She's mean. But dad says she'll toughen me up.

Angry Mar'hyah: Shut your mouth, Dringo. Last warning.

Angry Mar'hyah: Fine. You think you can do a better job without me - be my guest.

Sazza: Ya ain't gonna shoot me. Yer hands are shakin'.
NodeContext: mocking. Sazza is mocking Arka. Arka's hands ARE shaking and so is the crossbow.
Memnos: Put it down. She can't fight back.
Arka: That's the point. Get out of the way.
Memnos: She didn't kill your brother, Arka. You're better than this.
NodeContext: Sadly
Narrator: *Your mind wanders: If the crossbow bolt shot through her mouth, would she taste the metal before she died?*
Sazza: Shoot before you lose your nerve, tiefling. If you ever had it to begin with.
Player: This- This is wrong, isn't it?
Arka: I didn't ask for you to say a damn thing - keep out of it!
NodeContext: Addressing the player
Arka: Oh, I'll bless you all right.
NodeContext: grim and snappy
Player: Move in front of the tiefling's crossbow.
Player: Step between the crossbow and the goblin.

NodeContext: Laughs
Arka: You! Move!
NodeContext: to goblin, then to player
Player: This won't avenge Kanon. It won't change anything.
Arka: You're right. I wish you weren't, I really do.
Arka: Damn you. Damn it!

Arka: Gods, you're exhausting. Fine, then.
Arka: Can't say I understand that. Not sure I want to.
Memnos: It's all right, Arka. Let's go.

Zevlor: Your help at the gate was appreciated.
Zevlor: Never thought I'd say this to a drow, but... thank you. I'm Zevlor. And you're...?
Player: I'm [GEN_PlayerName_c11eee1e-7815-6143-7233-f2427799fa53].
Zevlor: Well met. Though I should warn you - visitors are no longer welcome in this grove.
Zevlor: Whatever your business here, I'd see to it quickly - the druids are forcing everyone out.
Zevlor: This latest attack will only strengthen their resolve.
Player: I have no quarrel with druids.
Zevlor: There have been several attacks by different monsters. The druids blame us 'outsiders' for drawing them here. Nobody's welcome anymore.
Zevlor: They've started a ritual to cut the grove off from the world outside.
Zevlor: We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: What brought you here?
Zevlor: We're refugees from Elturel - we took shelter here after goblins and gnolls attacked us on the road.
Zevlor: We were bound for Baldur's Gate, and it was too late to turn back. Elturel had no place for tieflings after the Descent.
Player: You made it back from Avernus. Surely you can survive anything?
Zevlor: So I hoped. But we've lost so many already - and more will die if we're forced out again.
Zevlor: We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.

Player: If your people survived that, they'll survive anything.

Player: I was there, you know. I'd hoped you'd had a happy ending.
Zevlor: We got out alive. That's what matters. And you did too, by the looks of things.
Zevlor: We'll live to tell another tale, if we can just convince these druids not to turn us out on our backsides.
Zevlor: We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.

Fezzerk: Apologies, your grace. We didn't mean to doubt a True Soul. We'll be off.

Balthazar: Finally, we can talk face-to-face.
Balthazar: Not just any True Soul would have succeeded in following my path through this place. You should be pleased.
Balthazar: I take it the breaking of my skeletons was an accident - the living are so clumsy, after all.
Player: I'm pleased to be of service, Balthazar.
Balthazar: Perhaps you can prove to me that you're more useful alive than dead. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Balthazar: But you're here now, and I may be able to put those limbs to work. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Player: Z'rell said Ketheric wants you to find a relic. That's all I know.
Player: As you mention serving Ketheric, he sent you to find a relic, no?
Balthazar: General Thorm to you. But yes, recovering the relic is the crux of it. He commands, and I, his humble servant, fulfil that command.
Balthazar: While you, an infinitely more humble servant, fulfil my command. I will put you to work - as a scout.
Narrator: *This necromancer has Ketheric's trust. Helping him could be just what you need to gain access to the man himself.*
Player: Jobs like this always go smoother when I know exactly what I'm looking for.
Player: I need more to go on. Why is this relic so important? What does it do?
Balthazar: Telling you will not make the task any less perilous. Just obey, and use your ignorance as a shield. You should be adept at that already.
Balthazar: The Nightsong lends the General his strength, his invulnerability. It must be recovered, before his enemies attempt to exploit it.
Player: You need my help?
Balthazar: I do not need you, or your help. But you are here in spite of that, so I may as well make use of you.
Balthazar: The Nightsong is close, but the way is barred and Shar's dead are... uncooperative. Clear the path for me - by blade, cunning, or whatever it takes.
Balthazar: I will remain here until you have succeeded, or fallen.
Shadowheart: I'd trust this gasbag about as far as I can throw him - which isn't far. But perhaps better to play along, for now.
Player: For jobs like this it's good form to provide your operatives some extra resources.
Balthazar: Fine. I will assign Flesh to aid you on your way. Ring this bell...
Balthazar: ...and he will come.
Balthazar: My brother is no intellectual powerhouse, but he is strong, loyal and punctual. Should a fight turn against you, remember the bell.
Player: Attack.

Kith'rak Voss: What easy prey you make, walking right within my blade's embrace.
Kith'rak Voss: These creatures are so simple to ensnare, Baretha. You mewl too much about your task.
Sarth Baretha: Forgiveness, Kith'rak.
Kith'rak Voss: And as for you, tell me - why shouldn't I run you through this instant?
Player: You'd sprain your wrist trying.
Kith'rak Voss: Senseless creature - I don't want to dull my blade on your overly thick skull.
Kith'rak Voss: But your bravery amuses me. Finally I find a wolf in a world of lowing cattle...
Kith'rak Voss: You may live. For the moment.
Kith'rak Voss: Now, we seek a weapon, taken from a vessel that fell from the sky. Understand, istik?
Narrator: *You suddenly feel a strange anxiety take hold - not your own, but that of the artefact you carry. Somehow, it's afraid...*
Narrator: *You attune your mind to it. The artefact does not want to part from you. It does not want to fall into the gith raiders' hands.*
Narrator: *Her mind focuses - the giths' suspicion cannot be aroused. They cannot discover that the weapon they seek is right within their grasp.*
Kith'rak Voss: Help us find it and I will leave your blood beneath your skin, unspilled.
Shadowheart: Don't help them. Don't tell them a thing. We're dead if you do.
Player: I might know something. But it'll cost you.
Kith'rak Voss: You haggle with your own life, fool. Be silent and hold still...
Narrator: *He begins to move his hand in a quick flurry of gestures.*
NodeContext: Narration.
Player: He is casting Detect Thoughts - steel your mind to resist it.
Player: Resist the probing into your mind.
Kith'rak Voss: Bah! Nothing even approaching a useful thought in that skull. I ought to just kill you...
Player: I could help if you let me live - search for this weapon, perhaps.
Kith'rak Voss: Unlikely you'd be successful... but it costs me nothing to spare your sorry life.
Kith'rak Voss: Very well, istik. Seek out survivors from the ship that crashed on this wretched world.
Kith'rak Voss: Bring me their heads. Bring me the weapon. If you succeed, the reward will be great.
Kith'rak Voss: Now go.

Shadowheart: Everyone seems to be in high spirits.
NodeContext: Shadowheart and the player standing throughout this dialogue, chatting in a party setting. Shadowheart has a glass of wine in hand,
Shadowheart: I saw you with Karlach. You two looked... cosy.
Shadowheart: Far be it from me to judge. Blood must still be running a little hot after everything.
Shadowheart: Strange... you know who I never thought I'd find myself caring for?
Player: Me?
Shadowheart: I wouldn't quite say that... but no, that's not what I mean.
Shadowheart: I mean desperate people... like those refugees. Never gave them much thought. Certainly not that bunch in the grove.
Shadowheart: Yet we came through for them. We saved their lives. Odd.
Player: Sounds like the wine is talking.
Shadowheart: It's not talking enough for my liking.
NodeContext: 'Wish I had something stronger'. Holding up her glass and considering its contents in a playful critique.
Shadowheart: Share a bottle with me?

Shadowheart: Just a bottle. I think you have other plans afterwards - wouldn't want to keep you.
Shadowheart: ...Well, maybe I would. But first come, first served.
Player: Maybe those plans could change, for the right person...
Narrator: *Shadowheart says nothing, but the glimmer of interest in her eyes is unmistakable.*
Player: I'll find you later, once the camp's asleep.

Raphael: Go on. Partake. Enjoy your supper. After all...

Shadowheart: This must be the last step. I need to pray. Only by Lady Shar's grace did we even make it this far.
Player: Lady... Shar? You worship her...?
Shadowheart: I do. I'm amazed you missed the signs, honestly.
Shadowheart: Now let me pray. This is important.
Player: Use the power of the parasite. Feel inside Shadowheart's mind.
Narrator: *You feel your mind slip into Shadowheart's - but you are not the only one present. There is another - ancient, commanding, rendered from purest darkness. Shar.*
Shar: ...Find my spear, step forward, and strike down the Selûnite.
Shadowheart: As you command, Nightsinger.
Shar: Now go. Warm my blade with moon-crazed blood. And be wary of your companion - they pry in your thoughts.
Shadowheart: That wasn't for you to hear.
Player: I deserve to know what I'm getting myself into.
Shadowheart: It's simple. My Lady Shar demands a sacrifice. One life.
Shadowheart: Not that it matters, but her reward aligns with your own interests.
Player: All right. Fine. Let's move on.
Shadowheart: No. Not yet. We can't go on - not without the Spear of Night. We must return to the library.
Player: I don't care about the spear - I'm continuing.
Shadowheart: My Lady does not want you to.
Shadowheart: Please. Don't make me do this - not after all we've been through.
NodeContext: Imploring someone she respects to change their mind, or she'll be forced to attack them
Player: Fine - we'll go look for the spear first.
Shadowheart: Good. Somewhere in the library there should be an image of my Lady that we can shroud in darkness. The spear should reveal itself.

Shadowheart: What do you know about me? You spoke of my past, being chased by wolves - I told no one about that...
Shadowheart: ...Almost no one. But I certainly didn't share that with you.
Nightsong: There is nothing I can tell you that you do not already know yourself. They trained you well, trained you hard. Chiselled away any part of you that did not fit their plan. They made you forget.
Shadowheart: I chose to do that. For the mission. To protect Shar's -
Nightsong: - secrets. Yes, yes. That is an old song, girl. Your goddess cares more for her precious secrets than she does her devotees.
Shadowheart: Get to the point.
Nightsong: When you freed me, you severed a bond between me and that dog, Thorm. A bond of pain - his, inflicted on me.
Nightsong: When I laid eyes on you, I sensed a similar bond. You, tethered to two others, someplace distant. Let me help you remember.
Narrator: *You feel Shadowheart's mind tug at the edges of your thoughts. She wants you to stay with her, to see whatever is about to be revealed to you.*
Narrator: *You feel Shadowheart's mind tug at the edges of your own. You know this sensation. She wants you to see whatever is about to be revealed.*
Player: Open your mind to that sensation.
Narrator: *Your mind joins with Shadowheart's. Something pulls at you both, bringing you elsewhere...*
Shadowheart: What... who was that man?
Nightsong: You already know. Did you not see yourself in him? Do you not recognise your own blood?
Shadowheart: My father? That was him?
Nightsong: That is him. He lives still, and your mother too.
Shadowheart: No, it can't be. I'm an orphan.
Nightsong: And who told you that? Your adoptive family? You are not to blame. You were young, impressionable. They took you because they wanted to break and remake you.
Nightsong: But you are a child no longer. You are a woman. One who knows what must be done.
Shadowheart: My parents. I need to save them.
Player: I'll help.
Nightsong: Your parents are with your abductors. You will need to return to their lair. But be warned.

NodeContext: Shadowheart and the player standing throughout this dialogue, chatting in a party setting. Shadowheart has a glass of wine in hand,
Shadowheart: I saw you with Wyll. You two looked... cosy.

Shadowheart: Strange... you know who I never thought I'd find myself caring for?

Narrator: *Shadowheart says nothing, but the glimmer of interest in her eyes is unmistakable.*

Narrator: *Your suspicions have proven true. This is the Gauntlet of Lady Shar. Perhaps here, you can show yourself to be worthy. A Dark Justiciar, at last.*
Shadowheart: The Gauntlet of Shar.This place is legendary - even with half my memories locked away, I still remember the stories...
Shadowheart: The Dark Lady's finest warriors arose from this place - and now I'm here.
